Title: South American population history revisited: multidisciplinary perspectives on the Upper Amazon

This project seeks to uncover the complex population history of the Upper Amazon in western South America, a region characterized by remarkable linguistic diversity. By employing a multidisciplinary approach, we will reconstruct and compare geographical, socio-historical, and communicative layers of history to shed light on past events such as migrations, language shifts, exogamy, and trade. Our study will investigate the interaction between ecology, human behavior, and cognition, and explore how these factors have shaped the region's linguistic diversity.

The Upper Amazon is a unique laboratory for understanding linguistic diversity, with distinct patterns in the north and south, and a central region dominated by three language families. Our research will integrate insights from linguistics, history, archaeology, anthropology, and ecology to provide a comprehensive understanding of the region's population history. By reconstructing the geographical, socio-historical, and communicative layers of history, we will uncover the social dynamics that have shaped linguistic diversity in the Upper Amazon.

The potential findings of this project have significant implications for our understanding of human history, highlighting the importance of linguistic diversity as a window into our past. Our research will provide new insights into the complex relationships between ecology, human behavior, and cognition, and shed light on the historical processes that have shaped the cultural and linguistic landscape of the Upper Amazon.
